titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Elaine Lobl Konigsburg Papers, 1967-1986 SC.1986.01
titlestmt.author: Jennifer Needham.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:01:24 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Elaine Lobl Konigsburg (February 10, 1930-April 19, 2013) was a writer and illustrator of children's books and young adult fiction and one of six writers to win two Newbery Medals. The collections contains material relating to her books published between 1967 and 1991, including: manuscripts, typescripts, galleys, some correspondence with publishers, dust jackets, original illustrations and art.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Elaine Lobl Konigsburg (February 10, 1930-April 19, 2013) was a writer and illustrator of children's books and young adult fiction. Born in New York City in 1930, she grew up in Pennsylvania and graduated as valedictorian of her Farrell, Pa., high school. Shortly after, she met her husband, David Konigsburg, at a meatpacking plant where she worked as a bookkeeper.

She received her undergraduate degree at the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University), where she majored in chemistry and continued her studies as a graduate student at the University of Pittsburgh. She soon realized that chemistry might not be the career path for her, as she is quoted as saying: "Long before I began writing, long before I had children, I was a chemist. Determined to push back the frontiers of science, I continued studying chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh graduate school. After two years there I found that the only thing I had succeeded in pushing back was my hairline, I twice blew up a laboratory sink, losing my eyebrows and banks in a flash."

She relocated to Jacksonville, Florida, after her husband was offered a job as an industrial psychologist. There, Elaine taught at the Bartram School for Girls until 1955, when she gave birth to her first child, Paul. Elaine would have two more children, Laurie and then Ross, in 1955 and 1959. While raising her children, she took painting lessons through a local adult education program.

After the family relocated again, this time to Port Chester, New York, and once all three children were in school, Elaine began to write. Her first published book was Jennifer, Hecate, Macbeth, William McKinley, and Me, Elizabeth in 1967, which was a Newbery Honor winner and selected byBook Week Magazine as an honor book for its 1967 Children's Spring Book Festival. This was followed, in the same year, by From, the Mixed-up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler, which was awarded a Newbery Medal. For both, she used her children as the models for illustrations. In the 1973 film version of the book, Ingrid Bergman played the role of Mrs. Frankweiler, which was also made into a television movie in 1995, with Lauren Bacall in the same role.
Konigsburg went on to publish over 20 books. In 1997, she won a second Newbery Medal for The View from Saturday, making her one of six writers to win two Newbery Medals.

"Many of Konigsburg's stories feature childhood and adolescent struggles that are easy for school-age readers to understand. Often her characters are striving to find the answers to big questions that will help shape their identities. Many of them are based on her own experiences as a child, the observations she made of children while a teacher, and the experiences or observations of her children."
Konigsburg passed away in Falls Church, Va., on April 19, 2013.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: The collection originally contained the following foreign language first editions that were shelved with the Elizabeth Nesbitt Room general collection and are now located in storage, part of Special Collection's Nesbitt Collection, and can be requested for in-library use in the reading room:
First editions ofJennifer, Hecate, Macbeth, William McKinley, and Me, Elizabeth from Germany, Finland, and Norway
First editions ofFrom the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler from Germany, Japan, Netherlands, and Norway

p.title: Samuel Todd's Book of Great Colors

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in the following 15 series by book title and according to publication date. The final series contains oversize materials:
Series I. Jennifer, Hecate, Macbeth, William McKinley, and Me, Elizabeth
Series II. From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler
Series III. About the B'nai Bagels
Series IV. Altogether, One at a Time
Series VI. A Proud Taste for Scarlet and Miniver
Series VII. The Dragon in the Ghetto Caper
Series VIII. The Second Mrs. Giaconda
Series XI. Journey to an 800 Number
Series XII. Up from Jericho Tel
Series XIII. Samuel Todd's Book of Great Colors
Series XIV. Samuel Todd's Book of Great Inventions
Series XVI. Correspondence to Amy Kellman

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Elaine Lobl Konigsburg in 1986. Series XVI, Gift of Amy Kellman in 2020.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The collection was originally housed in the Elizabeth Nesbitt Room at the University of Pittsburgh's Information Science Library. After the library's closure in 2012, the collection was transferred to the University of Pittsburgh Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Elaine Lobl Konigsburg Papers include material relating to her books published between 1967 and 1991, including: manuscripts, typescripts, galleys, some correspondence with publishers, dust jackets, original illustrations and art.

Series are arranged in chronological order according to the date of publication. Folders within each series are arranged according to the order of the publication process. Both series and folders remain in the same arrangement as when received from the Information Sciences Library, excluding galley proofs and illustrations which are now located within oversized materials.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was originally processed by the Information Science Library's Elizabeth Nesbitt Room in 1986. In 2014, the collection was rehoused by Jennifer Needham and student employee, Lauren Galloway.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Elaine Lobl Konigsburg Papers, 1967-1986, SC.1986.01, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Elaine Lobl Konigsburg Papers, 1967-1986, SC.1986.01, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

did.unittitle: Jennifer, Hecate, Macbeth, William McKinley, and me, Elizabeth

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to Konigsburg's first published book, Jennifer, Hecate, Macbeth, William McKinley, and Me, Elizabeth., published in 1967. Although none of the material within the series is dated, based the book's publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the 1960's. The series is arranged according to the editing and publication process and includes handwritten manuscripts and typescripts, notes, proofs, and dust jackets. Galley proofs and illustrations are included in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Typescript with notes to typesetter and corrections
Handwritten notes with references to galley and book
Illustrations with Jennifer's notes in script mounted on typeset leaves
Folded and gathered proof and dust jacket
From the Mixed-up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Found in this series are materials related to Konigsburg's second book, From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler, published in 1967. Although a majority of the material within the series is not dated, based on the books publication date and what is dated, materials were most likely created throughout the mid 1960's. The series is arranged according to the editing and publications process and includes typescripts, proofs, correspondence, and proposed dust jackets. Galley proofs and illustrations are located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Folded and gathered proof and correspondence
Dust jackets (2), one with Newbery Medal
Photo reproductions of museum floor plans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are materials related to Konigsburg's third book, About the B'nai Bagels, published in 1969. Although everything but the correspondence is undated, of the material within based on the books publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the mid to late 1960's. Included are handwritten manuscripts and typescripts, proofs, and correspondence. Oversize materials, like galley proofs and illustrations are included in Series XV.

did.unittitle: Typescript with Jacket and Dedication Information
Correspondence from H. Goldstein from Atheneum

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials related to the publication of Konigsburg's fourth book, Altogether, One at a Time, a short story collection published in 1971. Included are handwritten manuscripts and typescripts-many with revisions, notes, and correspondence. Although very little of the material within the series is dated, based on the books publication date those items that are dated, materials were most likely created throughout mid to late 1960's. There is one galley proof which is located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Handwritten Notes, "Specific Dyslexia" and "The Last Skill Acquired"
Typescript, "Night of the Leonids," including letter to Jean Karl
Partial Manuscript, "The Night of the Leonids"
Typescript, "Camp Fat," with corrections and revisions
Black and White Photo Reproductions of Illustrations, "Camp Fat"
Handwritten Manuscript, "Momma at the Pearly Gates"
Typescript with Revisions, "Momma at the Pearly Gates"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This small series includes materials related to George, published in 1971. The title actually appears as (george). Two items are included in this small series, notes and sketches and a manuscript. Although none of the material within the series is dated, based on the books publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the late 1960's.

did.unittitle: A Proud Taste for Scarlet and Miniver

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are materials related to Konigsburg's fictionalized account of Eleanor of Aquitaine, A Proud Taste for Scarlet and Miniver, publised in 1973. Handwritten manuscripts and typescripts, correspondence, proofs, and proposed dust jackets make up this series. Although the only dated materials within the series is correspondence, based on this and the book's publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the late 1960's and early 1970's.

did.unittitle: The Dragon in the Ghetto Caper

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials related to Konigsburg's 7th book, The Dragon in the Ghetto Caper, published in 1974. Although a majority of the material within the series is not dated, based on the books publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the early 1970's. Included are handwritten manuscripts and typescripts, proofs, and correspondence. Oversize materials, such as galley proofs and illustrations can be found in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Color selection chart card with green swatches
Correspondence to Matt Martino from Harriet Barton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are items related to The Second Mrs. Gianconda, a historical novel featuring Leonardo da Vinci, published in 1975. Although very little of the material within this series is dated, based on the books publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the early 1970's. Included are handwritten manuscripts and typescripts, notes, correspondence, proofs, and the dramatization of the book make up this series. One galley proof and a dramatization of the book book, are located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Dramatization of book-manuscript and notes, partly handwritten

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes typescripts for Father's Arcane Daughter, published in 1976. It was later published asMy Father's Daughter. Although none of the material within the series is dated, according the book's publication date, materials were most likely created throughout early to mid- 1970's. There is one galley proof located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Typescript, some pages handwritten and some pages missing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes handwritten manuscripts, typescripts, and a gathered proof for Throwing Shadows, a short story collection published in 1979. Although none of the material within the series is dated, based on the books publication date, materials were most likely created throughout the mid 1970's. One galley proof is located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Typescript, missing section under heading "On Shark's Tooth Beach"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are materials related to Journey to an 800 Number, published in 1982. Handwritten manuscripts, typescripts, and correspondence make up this series. Although the only dated materials are the correspondence, based on this and the publication date, materials were most likely created during the late 1970's and early 1980's. Oversize illustrations are located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Robert Lescher and Jean Karl

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes typescripts, correspondence, and photographs for Konigsburg's only speculative fiction novel, Up From Jericho Tel, published in 1986. The only dated material in the series is the correspondence, but based on this and the book's publication date, materials were most likely created during the early to mid-1980's. One galley proof for the novel can be found in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Correspondence from Jean Karl, Jonathan J. Lanman, and Michele A. Foley
Drafts of Cover Art and Final Dust Jacket
Samuel Todd's Book of Great Colors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are materials related to Konigsburg's picture book, Samuel Todd's Book of Great Colors, published in 1990. Originally created just for her grandson, Samuel Todd, her editor, decided it should be published. Materials included are the original handmade book, typescript, various proofs, correspondence, and rough cuts of the printed pages. One galley proof is located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Photograph of Samuel Todd in Jon Lauman's office with note
Samuel Todd's Book of Great Inventions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the children's picture book Samuel Todd's Book of Great Inventions, published in 1991, and includes typescripts, proofs, correspondence, and proposed dust jackets. Box 14 contains all of the illustrations for the book, located in Series XV, "Oversize Materials."

did.unittitle: Dummy 2-carried to NYC on 6/14/1990 and shown to J.K., J.L. and B.F.
Galley proofs and memo from editor
Photographs of Samuel Todd with notes
Promotional material-MacMillan catalog Fall 1991 and correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains galley proofs and illustrations and is divided between 3 boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence by Konigsburg with Amy Kellman, a children's librarian and later the Coordinator of Chirldren's Services for the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh. Correspondence consists of communications between friends and colleagues related to the early years of Konigsburg writing career.
